disease_data.name: Early Blight
disease_data.symptoms: Small, dark spots with concentric rings that look like a target. It usually starts on the oldest leaves near the ground and turns them yellow.
disease_data.cause: A soil-borne fungus called Alternaria solani.
disease_data.organic_treatment: Prune infected lower leaves and apply Neem oil or a baking soda spray to reduce spread.
disease_data.chemical_treatment: Apply fungicides containing Chlorothalonil or Copper-based sprays every 7 to 10 days.
disease_data.prevention: Rotate crops every 2 years, use mulch to prevent soil splash, and avoid overhead watering.

disease_data.name: Septoria Leaf Spot
disease_data.symptoms: Numerous small, circular spots with dark borders and greyish-white centers. Tiny black specks may appear inside the spots.
disease_data.cause: A fungus that thrives in high humidity and wet foliage.
disease_data.organic_treatment: Remove and destroy all infected leaves immediately. Improve airflow by staking the plants.
disease_data.chemical_treatment: Use fungicides containing Mancozeb or Potassium Bicarbonate.
disease_data.prevention: Keep leaves dry by using drip irrigation and ensure 24-inch spacing between plants.

The name of the disease is Septoria leaf spot caused by a fungus that thrives in high humidity and wet foliage. The symptoms include numerous small, circular spots with dark borders and greyish-white centers, with tiny black specks that may appear inside the spots. Organic treatment involves removing and destroying all infected leaves immediately and improving airflow by staking the plants. Chemical treatment includes using fungicides containing Mancozeb or Potassium Bicarbonate. To prevent this disease, keep leaves dry by using drip irrigation and ensure 24-inch spacing between plants.

disease_data.name: Late Blight
disease_data.symptoms: Large, irregular greenish-black water-soaked patches on leaves. In humid weather, a white fuzzy growth may appear on the leaf undersides.
disease_data.organic_treatment: There is no cure. Pull out the entire plant and bag it immediately to prevent spore travel.
disease_data.chemical_treatment: Preventative spraying with Copper fungicides is effective, but once the disease is visible, chemicals rarely save the plant.
disease_data.prevention: Plant resistant varieties and destroy all potato tubers or volunteer tomatoes from the previous year.

disease_data.name: Bacterial Spot
disease_data.symptoms: Small, water-soaked spots that eventually turn dark brown and look 'scabby' or greasy. Can also cause spots on the fruit.
disease_data.cause: Bacteria spread by wind-blown rain and contaminated tools.
disease_data.organic_treatment: Apply a liquid copper spray. Remove any heavily infected plants to protect the rest of the crop.
disease_data.chemical_treatment: A combination spray of Copper and Mancozeb is the standard treatment.
disease_data.prevention: Only plant certified disease-free seeds and avoid handling plants when they are wet with dew or rain.

disease_data.name: Healthy Tomato Leaf
disease_data.symptoms: Leaves are vibrant green, firm, and free of spots, holes, or fuzzy growth.
disease_data.cause: Optimal growth conditions and good hygiene.
disease_data.prevention: Continue to clean your gardening tools after each use and monitor for pests like aphids weekly.
